content.title: Hemodynamic Monitoring in Critical Care
content.summary: Hemodynamic monitoring in the ICU ranges from basic vital signs to advanced cardiac output measurement. The goal is assessing tissue perfusion adequacy and guiding resuscitation. Monitoring modalities include non-invasive (NIBP, pulse oximetry, echocardiography), minimally invasive (arterial line, pulse contour analysis), and invasive (PAC). Modern approaches favor less invasive techniques when possible, using dynamic parameters (PPV, SVV, PLR) to predict fluid responsiveness rather than static pressures (CVP).
key_points: Goal: Assess tissue perfusion and oxygen delivery adequacy
Basic: Heart rate, blood pressure, urine output, lactate
Arterial line: Continuous BP, waveform analysis, frequent ABGs
CVP: Poor predictor of fluid responsiveness; use dynamic parameters instead
Cardiac output: Thermodilution (PAC), pulse contour (FloTrac, PiCCO), echo
Dynamic parameters: PPV, SVV, PLR predict fluid responsiveness better than CVP
content.statement: Hemodynamic monitoring in critical care integrates clinical assessment, laboratory values, and technology-based measurements to evaluate perfusion adequacy, with modern emphasis on dynamic parameters over static pressures for guiding fluid resuscitation.

explanation.intuition: Hemodynamic monitoring answers the fundamental question: Is this patient's circulation delivering enough oxygen to their tissues? We use a ladder of monitoring intensity - from looking at the patient, to checking vital signs, to placing invasive monitors - based on how sick the patient is and how certain we need to be.
explanation.key_insight: CVP was once considered the key to fluid management, but studies show it's a poor predictor of fluid responsiveness. Dynamic parameters that measure the heart's response to volume changes (like watching blood pressure swing with ventilator breaths) are much better at predicting who will improve with fluids.
explanation.technical_details: Cardiac output = HR × SV. Oxygen delivery (DO2) = CO × CaO2. Oxygen consumption (VO2) measured by Fick principle. Pulse contour analysis estimates SV from arterial waveform analysis. PPV = (PPmax - PPmin) / PPmean × 100; >13% suggests fluid responsiveness in ventilated patients.

definitions_glossary.hemodynamic_monitoring: Assessment of cardiovascular function and tissue perfusion
definitions_glossary.cardiac_output: Volume of blood pumped per minute; CO = HR × SV
definitions_glossary.mean_arterial_pressure: MAP; average arterial pressure; MAP = DBP + 1/3(SBP - DBP)
definitions_glossary.CVP: Central venous pressure; right atrial pressure
definitions_glossary.pulse_pressure_variation: PPV; respiratory variation in pulse pressure predicting fluid responsiveness
definitions_glossary.stroke_volume_variation: SVV; respiratory variation in stroke volume
definitions_glossary.passive_leg_raise: PLR; reversible fluid challenge to test fluid responsiveness
definitions_glossary.pulse_contour_analysis: Cardiac output estimation from arterial waveform
definitions_glossary.lactate: Marker of tissue hypoperfusion; elevated in shock
definitions_glossary.ScvO2: Central venous oxygen saturation; surrogate for SvO2
definitions_glossary.oxygen_delivery: DO2; amount of oxygen delivered to tissues per minute
definitions_glossary.FloTrac: Minimally invasive cardiac output monitor using pulse contour

static_parameters.limitation: Poor predictors of fluid responsiveness; reflect preload status
static_parameters.CVP_evidence: Meta-analysis: CVP does NOT predict fluid responsiveness

PPV.requirements: Mechanical ventilation, Vt ≥8 mL/kg, sinus rhythm, no RV failure

passive_leg_raise.technique: Raise legs to 45° from supine; autotransfuses ~300 mL

goal_directed_therapy.approach: Optimize preload → assess contractility → adjust afterload

definition.@value: Assessment of cardiovascular function using clinical, laboratory, and technology-based parameters to guide resuscitation

scopeNote.@value: Dynamic parameters preferred over static pressures for fluid responsiveness

learning_objectives: Compare static and dynamic hemodynamic parameters
Assess fluid responsiveness using dynamic measures
Interpret lactate and ScvO2 in shock
Select appropriate monitoring modality for clinical scenario
clinical_pearls: CVP does NOT predict fluid responsiveness - use dynamic parameters
PPV >13% suggests fluid responsiveness in ventilated patients on ≥8 mL/kg Vt
Passive leg raise works even with arrhythmias and spontaneous breathing
Lactate clearance is more important than absolute value
MAP ≥65 is target; may need higher in chronic hypertension
common_misconceptions: CVP guides fluid therapy - poor predictor of response
High CO means adequate perfusion - distributive shock has high CO but poor perfusion
All monitoring is invasive - many less invasive options exist
